meanings.definition: To treat someone as an object rather than as a person.
meanings.sent1: Some people objectify others by only valuing their appearance.
meanings.sent2: It is important to remember not to objectify individuals based on stereotypes.
meanings.sent3: He joked that his cat would objectify him if it could speak.
meanings.sent4: In the world of advertising, it is common to objectify products to increase sales.
meanings.sent5: The artist's painting seemed to objectify the beauty of nature in a unique way.

meanings.definition: To make something into an object.
meanings.sent1: The sculptor can objectify a block of marble into a stunning statue.
meanings.sent2: When you objectify a concept, it becomes easier to understand.
meanings.sent3: The magician's trick seemed to objectify reality itself.
meanings.sent4: The writer's words had the power to objectify emotions into tangible images.
meanings.sent5: The chef's skill was to objectify simple ingredients into a gourmet dish.

meanings.definition: To view or treat someone as a sexual object.
meanings.sent1: It is harmful to objectify individuals solely based on their physical attributes.
meanings.sent2: Some movies tend to objectify women, which can perpetuate harmful stereotypes.
meanings.sent3: The comedian's joke about objectifying celebrities was met with mixed reactions.
meanings.sent4: The fashion industry often objectifies models, focusing only on their appearance.
meanings.sent5: The novel's protagonist struggled with being objectified by those around her.
